ecoli occurs naturally in the bovine

the government identified a coli o157 h7
as the bacteria responsible for the

the USDA left specific safety protocols

for e.coli slaughterhouses do some

these efforts vary greatly plant to

Cargill ground scraps of beef or trim
which are much cheaper than whole cuts
but particularly vulnerable to infection
any one of these sources could have been
responsible for the contamination that
sickened Stephanie Smith 38 percent of
the hamburger was from greater Omaha one
of the country's largest meatpacking
plants 37 percent was from Lone Star a
Texas slaughterhouse 15 percent was from
Uruguay where meat is subjected to even
less scrutiny than domestic supplies 10
percent wasn't solid beef at all but a
meat derivative manufactured by beef
products incorporated Cargill did not
test the trim from these suppliers as it
arrived at the Butler facility but some
companies like Costco believe testing
incoming trim is essential
Hostel owns a very large meat plant in
Tracy California where we do nothing but
grind meat it has to come in on what's
called a certificate of analysis which
means that the meat supplier has already
tested it then when it gets to our plant
we test it again we'll grind that meat
and make brown beef and then we want to
test it before it leaves also if it
doesn't pass we don't ship it but even
Costco's system which all experts say is
above and beyond the industry norm has a
vulnerability again we're blending some
lean meat with our trimmings and our

this is trimmings from these flank

ground beef that you saw on the retail

despite rigorous testing at the Tracy
meet facility the trim that is blended
with their ground beef comes from steaks
that are not tested for pathogens by
Costco this is a process common in the
grocery industry that potentially
introduces contaminants after testing is
completed on June 30th Costco recalled
ground beef that had been mixed using
trim from potentially contaminated
steaks from the JB's Swift corporation
no illnesses have been linked to Costco

the origin of the outbreak that sickened
Stephanie Smith as well as most
outbreaks remains a mystery but these
cases highlight the ground beef
industry's lack of transparency and the
consequences of the federal government's
willingness to defer control of safety
protocols to the private sector
